conclusion: Analyze forces acting on the small ball as it moves from point A to point B in the vertical tube, considering gravitational and electrostatic forces.
Gravitational force on the small ball is F_g = mg.
Small ball experiences electrostatic force due to point charges at points M and N.
Electrostatic force between the ball and point M is F_1 = k qQ / r_1^2.
Electrostatic force between the ball and point N is F_2 = k qQ / r_2^2.
Points M and N form an equilateral triangle with side length L.
Distances r_1 and r_2 are both equal to the circumradius of the equilateral triangle, r = L / sqrt(3).
Approximate r_1 and r_2 as R for simplicity since the ball is inside the tube and close to the vertical section.
Electrostatic forces F_1 and F_2 become F_1 = k qQ / R^2 and F_2 = k qQ / R^2.
Forces F_1 and F_2 act in opposite directions along the line connecting points M and N, perpendicular to the horizontal plane BCD.
Resultant force of F_1 and F_2 is zero since they are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.
Net electrostatic force exerted on the small ball when it reaches point B is 0.
